resources.string: The initial block download is not yet complete. It might take an hour or more. It may take a few minutes to find some initial nodes. You will not be able to send or confirm transactions until it is complete. You can request payments, you just won\'t be able to validate confirms.
The block chain data is loading. Some functions will be disabled until it finishes.

How often to synchronize the block chain with peer nodes. This involves connecting to peer nodes and downloading block headers and transactions. This is just referring to background synchronizing. Whenever the application is opened it will attempt to synchronize as well.
View Only. Wallet has a \"public only\" key and can not spend.

Select a date before the wallet(key) was originally created. It will take half an hour per year, or longer, to query all blocks for transactions from that time until now. It is often more convenient, when switching devices, to send the entire balance to a new wallet on the new device.
These transactions are not in the block chain yet and are not reflected in your balance.
Progress of synchronization with block chain.
Notifications when new transactions are found.
Payment Request Not For Main Network
Create a pass code to protect your private keys. You will be required to enter it when creating/adding keys or sending transactions.

These words are the \"mnemonic seed\" for your new wallet. You need to write this down and store this in a safe place so you can recover your wallet if you lose access to this device or forget your passcode. No one else can recover your bitcoins for you. Anyone who has access to this seed can spend all of your bitcoins.
Enter the words in your wallet\'s seed in order. Type the beginning of each word and click on the correct word when you see it.
Press continue when you have written down your \"mnemonic seed\".
This seed does not have a valid checksum built into it. Only use it if you are sure it is correct.
Send the code below to someone or have them scan this QR code for them to send you a payment.
This is a \"Legacy\" address! Do not send Bitcoin Cash to it unless you are sure that they want Bitcoin Cash (BCH) and not Bitcoin (BTC).
Prices (Exchange Rates) are averaged from the sources below.
Cryptographic Library - secp256k1 Copyright © 2013 Pieter Wuille
QR Library - Copyright © Zebra Crossing (zxing) https://github.com/zxing/zxing

Bitcoin Cash is peer to peer money. Anyone with a smart phone or computer can install a wallet and send and receive it. Creating a wallet only requires a wallet app to generate a large random number. To receive Bitcoin Cash just create a wallet and give someone an \"address\" (hash of one of your wallet\'s public keys). To send Bitcoin Cash just enter someone else\'s \"address\" into your wallet and create a transaction to pay them.

Bitcoin is an open source software project that is attempting to build a worldwide decentralized currency. Its goal is to allow people to pay each other without dependence on any company or government and without requiring permission from any company or government.

Bitcoin Cash is a branch of the Bitcoin project that is focused on increasing capacity and increasing usability and adoption. This wallet exclusively uses Bitcoin Cash. If you held Bitcoin on August 1st, 2017 then you hold that amount of Bitcoin Cash because the ledger up until that point is the same for both Bitcoin (BTC) and Bitcoin Cash (BCH).
How do I get Bitcoin Cash?

You can get Bitcoin Cash from anyone who has some and is willing to part with it to show you how it works. Just ask them to send you a little. Most people will be happy to. If you can\'t find anyone to give you some for free, or you want more than that, you can buy Bitcoin Cash and other major cryptocurrencies from Coinbase.com. They are a large exchange based in the United States. They will charge you a small fee to convert your money into cryptocurrency. If you use this link or the button on the main screen to sign up, then you will get $10 free when you buy $100 or more. https://www.coinbase.com/join/597a904283ff1a00a71aae6c
Why should I use Bitcoin Cash as opposed to other payment options?

Bitcoin Cash allows you to send money digitally to anyone in the world nearly instantaneously. It requires no third party like a bank or PayPal. Your transaction is transmitted to a peer to peer network and if accepted will be included and secured in the block chain that becomes more immutable (unchangeable) as blocks are added to it.
What is the initial block download?

Initial Block Download (IBD) is required every time a new \"node\" starts. It will only have to be done once after you install this app. It is the process of querying the network for blocks to find the block chain with the most \"proof of work\". After finding the block chain with the most \"proof of work\", downloading, and verifying each block header, your \"node\" (App) can then verify if transactions have been included in that block chain. This normally takes around an hour depending on the latency of your internet. It requires several hundred megabytes of data usage, so should be done on WiFi if possible. You may have to open the app occasionally to keep the download running as your phone may stop it after a while.

When your wallet says \"synchronizing\" under the name, that means the app is still querying the network to find transactions in the block chain that relate to your wallet. Either pay to or send from. This should only happen when you \"recover\" a wallet and the app is unsure of previous activity with that wallet. Creating a new wallet will not do this because there is no possibility of previous transactions.

When your wallet says \"Needs Backed Up\" under the name, that means you have not yet verified that you have written down the \"mnemonic seed\". You need to write down the mnemonic seed (list of words) to be able to recover your bitcoins if anything happens to your device. If you lose your mobile device or it breaks, and you do not have the seed, then no one can give your money back to you. This is because Bitcoin Cash is decentralized and no one has access to modify anyone else\'s bitcoins without knowing the private keys. If you do have your seed written down you can install most Bitcoin Cash wallet apps and enter your seed in the recover option to regain access to your bitcoins.

A mnemonic seed is a randomly generated list of words that represent numbers. Combined they represent a very large number, often with a checksum, that is used to derive the private keys for a wallet. Private keys are large numbers that give you access to send bitcoins. Anyone with your seed or private keys can send your bitcoins to anyone they want so be careful when storing your seed and who you give access to it. It is a good idea to write it on paper and put it in a safe or somewhere that you would store money.

Confirms, or confirmations, is the count of the number of blocks built on top of the block that a transaction is in. Each block built on top of the block a transaction is in greatly reduces the chances of the transaction every being removed from the block chain.

A double spend is a fraudulent action involving sending a payment to someone, then making a new transaction paying someone else or themselves with the same bitcoins. This can invalidate a transaction previously sent as bitcoins, like all good money, can only be spent once. When a transaction is pending (not in a block yet) it is possible that there is another transaction out there that conflicts with it and can invalidate it if included in a block. The more nodes that have accepted your transaction while pending, the more likely it is that it is valid and will be included in a block.
Why does it say I need to \"use pending\" when I have enough balance not pending?

When you send a payment you \"cash in\" a certain amount of \"coins\" of varying amounts, also called UTXOs. Usually the total amount you \"cash in\" is more than what you are sending. So you send the remaining balance back to yourself in a \"change\" address. If a previous send transaction is still pending, then so is the \"change\" which you may need to make the next payment. If you \"use pending\", then this transaction can\'t confirm until the pending transaction has confirmed. They can confirm at the same time though and that is most likely. It is up to the merchant whether they will accept payments based on pending UTXOs or not, so do it with caution.
What are the units of Bitcoin?

There are many units of measure in Bitcoin. The smallest unit is called a \"satoshi\". The common unit is called a \"bitcoin\". A bitcoin is equal to 100,000,000 satoshis. Another common unit is \"bits\". A bitcoin is equal to 100 bits. \"Bitcoin\" with a upper case \"B\" is the system and/or project. \"bitcoin\" with a lower case \"b\" is a unit of Bitcoin. This app uses a space delimited format for representing quantities that looks like this \"1 23 456 678\". Where the entire number is the satashis. The number before the first space is bitcoins. The numbers combined before the second space is the bits.

A Bitcoin address is a hash of a public key. It allows anyone to create a Bitcoin transaction sending bitcoins to the owner of the public key. There are many types of Bitcoin transactions in Bitcoin, but the standard transaction allows the coins to be spent by providing the full public key associated with a specified hash and proving access to the private key of that public key with a signature.

A hash is a method of turning a set of data into a specific value that can be repeated, but not reversed. For example anyone could take the data set and create the same hash data from it, but no one could take the hash and figure out the data set that created it. They can only verify that the data set corresponds to the hash when given both.

A Bitcoin key is a generated value that can be used for cryptographic functions. A private key can sign and decrypt data. A public key can verify signatures and encrypt data. In Bitcoin public keys can be used to verify signatures to cryptographically prove that the creator of a transaction has the private key associated with the public key. Check out Wikipedia for more information. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-key_cryptography

Proof of work involves using bulk cryptographic operations to solve a problem to prove that a miner spent actual effort to produce something. Proof of work is one of the backbones of Bitcoin, along with cryptographic signatures. Signatures allow nodes to prove ownership of public keys. Proof of work allows nodes to verify the ledger that is agreed upon by the most miners. Proof of work provides immutability (inability to change) the ledger, since any good money requires an immutable ledger. Check out Wikipedia for more information. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof-of-work_system
